raw_text:
Dollar hits new low versus euro
 
 The US dollar has continued its record-breaking slide and has tumbled to a new low against the euro.
 
 Investors are betting that the European Central Bank (ECB) will not do anything to weaken the euro, while the US is thought to favour a declining dollar. The US is struggling with a ballooning trade deficit and analysts said one of the easiest ways to fund it was by allowing a depreciation of the dollar. They have predicted that the dollar is likely to fall even further.
 
 The US currency was trading at $1.364 per euro at 1800 GMT on Monday. This compares with $1.354 to the euro in late trading in New York on Friday, which was then a record low.
 
 The dollar has weakened sharply since September when it traded about $1.20 against the euro. It has lost 7% this year, while against the Japanese yen it is down 3.2%. Traders said that thin trading levels had amplified Monday's move. "It's not going to take much to push [the dollar] one way or the other," said Grant Wilson of Mellon Bank. Liquidity - a measure of the number of parties willing to trade in the market - was about half that of a normal working day, traders said.
llama3.2:1b: The US dollar has hit new lows against the euro, with investors betting the ECB will not intervene and the US favoring a declining dollar due to its ballooning trade deficit. The currency fell 7% this year, with Monday's price at $1.364 per euro compared to $1.354 in late New York. Thin trading levels have amplified the move, while liquidity was about half that of a normal working day.
llama3.2:3b: US dollar reaches new low against euro at $1.364 per euro, down 7% this year, as investors bet on ECB not intervening and US favors declining dollar due to trade deficit issues.
gemma2:2b: The US dollar has reached a new low against the euro, trading at $1.364 per euro. This decline is driven by investor expectations that the European Central Bank will not weaken the euro while the US aims for a declining dollar to fund its trade deficit.

qwen2.5:1.5b: US dollar hits new low against euro, driven by ECB's likely non-action and US plans for further dollar depreciation, despite US struggles with ballooning trade deficit.
qwen2.5:3b: The US dollar has hit new lows against the euro, trading at $1.364 per euro on Monday, down from $1.354 in late New York Friday and significantly weaker since September when it traded around $1.20. Analysts predict continued depreciation due to a struggling trade deficit and expectations that the US will not support its currency, while the ECB is unlikely to weaken the euro. The dollar has fallen 7% this year against the euro and 3.2% against the yen. Thin trading levels amplified Monday's movement in the currency market.

It has lost 7% this year while against the Japanese yen it is down 3.2%. The European Central Bank (ECB) predicts that the euro will not be weakened further, although traders believe that thin trading levels have amplified the dollar's move. Liquidity measure reflects the volume of trades in the market."

<think>
Okay, so I need to help summarize this text into a concise summary. Let me read through it first.

The main points are that the US dollar has continued its record-breaking slide and fell to a new low against the euro. Investors think the European Central Bank won't strengthen the euro, while the US is likely to decline the dollar. The US has a trade deficit, which could be partly due to a weaker dollar. They predict the dollar will fall further, comparing the current rate to past lows.

I should focus on key ideas: dollar's slide, impact on trade deficit, ECB stance, US economic conditions, and the exchange rate. I need to make sure all important details are included without adding extra information.
</think>

The US dollar has fallen sharply against the euro, continuing its record-breaking decline. Investors expect the European Central Bank (ECB) not to weaken the euro, while the US is likely to weaken the dollar due to trade deficits. The dollar's decline impacts a $27 trillion trade deficit, with weaker currency serving as an easy funding source. Comparing the current rate ($1.364 per euro) to a record low from late 2018 ($1.354), the US predicts continued depreciation. Liquidity was weak, with only half of a typical working day willing to trade.
tinyllama:1.1b: Concise summary: Investors are betting on US dollar decline and European Central Bank not doing anything to weaken euro, while US is struggling with a balance deficit, analysts predict a further depreciation of the greenback. This contrasts with $1.354 against euro in late trading in New York earlier this week, a record low since September, when it was trading at $1.20 against Japanese yen. The dollar has lost 7% this year and traded at $1.364 per euro as of Monday evening's London session.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US dollar is having its worst performance against the euro this year and has hit an all-time low in recent trading. Investors are betting on ECB (European Central Bank) intervention to weaken the euro, while many in the United States believe that the dollar should be allowed to decline. Analysts predict further deterioration in US trade deficit and say a depreciated dollar is an efficient funding mechanism for such an deficit. As of 1800 GMT on Monday, the US currency was trading at $1.364 per euro compared to $1.354 in late trading in New York on Friday. The dollar has weakened sharply since September when it traded about $1.20 against the euro. This year, it has lost 7% against the Japanese yen, while against the euro it has decreased by almost a third or 3.2%. Traders believe that thin trading levels have amplified Monday's move. Liquidity - the number of parties willing to trade in the market - was at its all-time low, causing a lack of confidence in the market.
